title_sort: walt whitman to john burroughs, 19 september 1881
title: Walt Whitman to John Burroughs, 19 September 1881
text: Concord Mass:MassachusettsSept:September 19 '81Dear JohnI keep on fairly in health & strength—have been out here a few days the guest of Mr & Mrs F B Sanborn—& everything most affectionate & hospitable from them both—& from others—Have had a curiously full and satisfactory time with Emerson—he came to see me Saturday evening early, Mrs E also, & staidstayed two hours—Yesterday I went there (by pressing invitation) to dinner, & staidstayed two hours—a wonderfully good two hours—the whole family were very cordial, including Mrs. E. & the son, Edward, a doctor, a fine, handsome, 'cute, glowing young man, with a beautiful wife and child—I took to them all—I cannot tell you how sweet and good (and all as it should be) Emerson look'dlooked and behaved—he did not talk, in the way of joining in any animated conversation, but pleasantly and hesitatingly & sparsely—fully enough—to me it seemed just as it should be—The book is about through—will appear last of October—every thing satisfactory—I go from here in about a week to Johnston's, cor:correspondence Mott avenue & 149th St.Street N.Y.New York—then to Camden—shall go to Canada this winter—Walt Whitman Walt Whitman to John Burroughs, 19 September 1881
